name: St. Maximilian Kolbe
summary: Maximilian Kolbe was a Polish Franciscan friar who volunteered to die in place of a stranger in the Nazi concentration camp of Auschwitz. He was canonized as a martyr of charity and is the patron saint of drug addicts, prisoners, families, and the pro-life movement. He was also a publisher and founded the Militia Immaculatae movement.
keyQuotes: No one in the world can change Truth. What we can do and should do is to seek truth and to serve it when we have found it.
Hatred is not a creative force. Love alone creates.

name: St. Teresa Benedicta of the Cross (Edith Stein)
summary: Edith Stein was a German Jewish philosopher who converted to Catholicism and became a Discalced Carmelite nun, taking the name Teresa Benedicta of the Cross. She was murdered in Auschwitz concentration camp during the Holocaust. She is a co-patron saint of Europe and was declared a Doctor of the Church in 1999.
keyQuotes: Do not accept anything as the truth if it lacks love. And do not accept anything as love which lacks truth.
The world is in flames. Are you impelled to put them out? Look at the Cross. From the open heart gushes the blood of the Saviour. This extinguishes the flames of hell.

name: St. Pio of Pietrelcina

locations.description: Served as Capuchin friar and priest

summary: Pio of Pietrelcina, commonly known as Padre Pio, was an Italian Capuchin friar, priest, and mystic who is venerated as a saint in the Catholic Church. He was known for bearing the stigmata for most of his life and for his reported abilities of bilocation, levitation, prophecy, and miraculous healings. He founded the House for the Relief of Suffering, a hospital in San Giovanni Rotondo.
keyQuotes: Pray, hope, and don't worry.
The life of a Christian is nothing but a perpetual struggle against self.

name: St. Teresa of Calcutta

locations.description: Founded Missionaries of Charity and served the poor in Calcutta

summary: Teresa of Calcutta, commonly known as Mother Teresa, was an Albanian-Indian Catholic nun and missionary who founded the Missionaries of Charity, a religious congregation dedicated to serving the poorest of the poor. She received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 and was canonized in 2016. Her work spread to over 130 countries, establishing hospices and homes for people with various needs.
keyQuotes: Not all of us can do great things. But we can do small things with great love.
If you judge people, you have no time to love them.
Give, but give until it hurts.

name: St. John XXIII
summary: Pope John XXIII, born Angelo Giuseppe Roncalli, was head of the Catholic Church from 1958 until his death in 1963. He is best known for convening the Second Vatican Council, which brought significant changes to the Church. Despite his short pontificate, he was known for his warmth, humor, and pastoral approach, earning him the nickname 'Good Pope John'.
keyQuotes: It often happens that I wake at night and begin to think about a serious problem and decide I must tell the Pope about it. Then I wake up completely and remember that I am the Pope.
Consult not your fears but your hopes and your dreams.

name: St. Paul VI
summary: Pope Paul VI, born Giovanni Battista Montini, was head of the Catholic Church from 1963 until his death in 1978. He continued and concluded the Second Vatican Council begun by John XXIII and implemented its reforms. He was the first pope to travel extensively and made historic visits to the Holy Land, the United Nations, and other countries. He issued the encyclical Humanae Vitae.
keyQuotes: If you want peace, work for justice.
Somebody should have told us right at the start of our lives that we are dying. Then we might live life to the limit, every minute of every day.

name: St. Faustina Kowalska

locations.description: Member of the Sisters of Our Lady of Mercy

summary: Faustina Kowalska was a Polish Roman Catholic nun and mystic who is venerated as a saint in the Catholic Church. She is known for her devotion to the Divine Mercy and for receiving revelations from Jesus Christ that she recorded in her diary. The Divine Mercy devotion and the image of Divine Mercy originated from her visions.
keyQuotes: Jesus, I trust in You.
I feel certain that my mission will not come to an end upon my death, but will begin.

writings.title: Diary: Divine Mercy in My Soul

name: St. Josemaría Escrivá
summary: Josemaría Escrivá was a Spanish Catholic priest who founded Opus Dei, an organization of laypeople and priests dedicated to the teaching that everyone is called to holiness and that ordinary life is a path to sanctity. He was canonized in 2002 by Pope John Paul II. Opus Dei has grown to include tens of thousands of members worldwide.
keyQuotes: Do everything for Love. Thus there will be no little things: everything will be big. Perseverance in little things for Love is heroism.
The ordinary, unspectacular flow of everyday life should be the setting for our sanctification.

name: St. Thérèse of Lisieux

locations.description: Carmelite nun, declared Doctor of the Church in 1997

summary: Thérèse of Lisieux, also known as the Little Flower, was a French Discalced Carmelite nun. Though she died in 1897, her influence grew significantly in the 20th century. She was declared a Doctor of the Church by Pope John Paul II in 1997, becoming one of only four women to receive this title. Her 'Little Way' of spiritual childhood has inspired millions.
keyQuotes: What matters in life is not great deeds, but great love.
The splendor of the rose and the whiteness of the lily do not rob the little violet of its scent nor the daisy of its simple charm.

name: St. Óscar Romero

locations.description: Archbishop of San Salvador, martyred for speaking out against injustice

summary: Óscar Romero was a Salvadoran Catholic prelate who served as the fourth Archbishop of San Salvador. He spoke out against poverty, social injustice, assassinations, and torture in El Salvador. He was assassinated while celebrating Mass in 1980, shortly after pleading with soldiers to stop carrying out the government's repression. He was canonized in 2018.
keyQuotes: I have frequently been threatened with death. I must say that, as a Christian, I do not believe in death without resurrection. If they kill me, I shall rise in the Salvadoran people.
A church that suffers no persecution but enjoys the privileges and support of the things of the earth - beware! - is not the true church of Jesus Christ.

name: Karl Rahner

locations.description: Jesuit priest and influential theologian, peritus at Vatican II

summary: Karl Rahner was a German Jesuit priest and theologian who is considered one of the most influential Catholic theologians of the 20th century. He served as a peritus (theological expert) at the Second Vatican Council and developed a theological method that sought to reinterpret traditional Catholic doctrine in light of modern philosophy and experience.
keyQuotes: The Christian of the future will be a mystic or he will not exist at all.
Grace is everywhere, even in the deepest darkness of human existence.

name: Henri de Lubac

locations.description: Jesuit priest, cardinal, influential theologian and peritus at Vatican II

summary: Henri de Lubac was a French Jesuit priest and cardinal who became one of the most influential theologians of the 20th century. He was a leading figure in the nouvelle théologie movement and served as a peritus at the Second Vatican Council. He made important contributions to ecclesiology, especially regarding the relationship between nature and grace.
keyQuotes: The Church is not an institution that we have been invited to run. We are simply the guests at the table, the servants of the mystery.
The mystery of the Church is the mystery of the Incarnation continued.

writings.title: Catholicism: Christ and the Common Destiny of Man
